resources.string: Password must be 6 digits or more
Health is wealth. Let us help protect your children.
Are you sure you want to delete this record?

Because vaccines do not prevent most childhood infections, they are not likely to alter the balance of cells that mediate allergic responses. In fact, several large, well-controlled studies have shown that children who receive vaccines are not at greater risk of having allergies or asthma.

Children with mild illnesses, such as fever, diarrhea, ear infections or upper respiratory infections, are typically able to receive vaccines. Studies have shown that children with mild illnesses are not at greater risk of experiencing side effects than healthy children who get vaccinated and the level of protection provided by the immunization is equivalent. In contrast, children with severe illnesses should not be vaccinated to avoid questions related to the cause of any symptoms that might occur.

The MMR vaccine, thimerosal in vaccines and receiving too many vaccines at one time have all been accused of causing autism. However, numerous large, well-controlled scientific studies have shown: Children who receive the MMR vaccine are not at increased risk of autism. The chance of getting autism is the same in children who received vaccines containing thimerosal and children who received vaccines without thimerosal. An alternative vaccination schedule does not reduce the risk of autism. These studies have proven that autism is not caused by the MMR vaccine, thimerosal in vaccines, or receiving too many vaccines at one time.

Some have suggested that vaccines cause chronic diseases, such as diabetes, multiple sclerosis or arthritis. However, vaccines do not induce an immune response vigorous enough to cause autoimmunity; studies have shown no link between vaccines and diabetes, multiple sclerosis, arthritis, or other autoimmune diseases.
The chickenpox vaccine is used to prevent chickenpox.
Before the chickenpox vaccine, one or two children in the U.S. died every week from chickenpox.
The chickenpox vaccine is a live, weakened viral vaccine.
• Pain, redness, swelling or soreness at the injection site.\n • Low-grade fever.\n • Rash with fewer than 10 blisters around the area of the shot or on other parts of the body.
REASONS TO GET THE CHICKENPOX VACCINE

• Chickenpox still exists.
 • Chickenpox can sometimes cause severe complications and even death.
 • Some people can't get the chickenpox vaccine and require protection from others.
 • Getting the chickenpox vaccine can offer protection from shingles as an adult.
 • The chickenpox vaccine is safe.
The diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis vaccines are used to prevent these diseases and are typically given in the U.S. in combined formulations.
Before these vaccines, about 1,800 people died from diphtheria, about 500 died from tetanus and about 8,000 died from pertussis every year.
The diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis vaccines are all inactivated toxoid vaccines.
• Pain, redness or swelling at the injection site.\n • Low-grade fever.\n • Drowsiness or crankiness .
REASONS TO GET THE DIPHTHERIA – TETANUS – PERTUSSIS VACCINES

• Disease caused by diphtheria can make a comeback.
 • Tetanus is not transmitted from person-to-person, but rather from the soil, so even if everyone around you is immunized, your chance of getting tetanus does not decrease.
 • Pertussis is very common and often misdiagnosed or underdiagnosed.
 • Pertussis immunization protects babies who are too young to have been immunized and for whom the disease can be fatal.
 • The vaccines are safe.
The hepatitis A vaccine is used to prevent hepatitis A.
Before the vaccine, every year about 70 people died from hepatitis A infections.
The hepatitis A vaccine is a killed viral vaccine.

• Pain, redness and tenderness at the injection site.
 • Headache.
 • Mild fever.
 • Feeling out of sorts.
 • Fatigue.
REASONS TO GET THE HEPATITIS A VACCINE

• It's hard to know who's contagious.
 • Eating at a restaurant can lead to hepatitis A infection.
 • Hepatitis A infections can be long-lasting.
 • Hepatitis A infections can cause death.
 • The hepatitis A vaccine is safe.
The hepatitis B vaccine is used to prevent hepatitis B.
Before the hepatitis B vaccine, every year about 18,000 children in the United States were infected with hepatitis B by the time they were 10 years old.
The hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine.

• Pain or soreness at the injection site.
 • Headache.
 • Mild fever.
 • Irritability.
 • Fatigue.
REASONS TO GET THE HEPATITIS B VACCINE

• Hepatitis B virus still infects about 100,000 people in the U.S. every year.
 • Many people do not know they are infected with hepatitis B virus.
 • The consequences of hepatitis B infection tend to be worse in younger people.
 • You can get hepatitis B through somewhat casual contact with an infected person, such as sharing toothbrushes or razors.
 • The hepatitis B vaccine is safe.
The Hib vaccine is used to prevent Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib).
Before the Hib vaccine, every year about 20,000 children would get serious, and sometimes fatal, infections with Hib.
The Hib vaccine is a conjugate vaccine.

• Pain or soreness at the injection site.
 • Low-grade fever.
 • Loss of appetite.
 • Irritability.
REASONS TO GET THE HIB VACCINE

• Hib still exists.
 • Infants and young children are the most susceptible to Hib.
 • Unvaccinated or incompletely vaccinated children are at higher risk of disease caused by Hib.
 • The Hib vaccine decreases the number of Hib carriers in the population.
 • The Hib vaccine is safe.
The influenza vaccine is used to prevent influenza.
Circulating strains of influenza virus may change each year, leading to almost annual changes to the influenza vaccine.
The influenza vaccine given as a shot is a killed viral vaccine. A newer version of influenza vaccine, also given as a shot, is made using recombinant DNA technology.

• Redness, soreness or hardening at the injection site.
 • Muscle aches.
 • Headache.
 • Low-grade fever.
REASONS TO GET THE INFLUENZA VACCINE

• Influenza is a common infection. • Children can easily spread influenza. • Influenza viruses often change each year, so getting the vaccine one year doesn\'€™t mean you\'€™ll be protected the next year. • A syndrome known as post-polio syndrome can occur later in life in people previously infected with polio. • Influenza can lead to other infections like pneumonia. • The influenza vaccine is safe.
The MMR vaccine is only available in the U.S. as a combination vaccine and is used to prevent measles, mumps and rubella.
Before the vaccines, measles, mumps and rubella were very damaging to pregnant women.
The MMR vaccine is a live, “weakened” viral vaccine.

• Low-grade fever.
 • Non-contagious measles-like rash.
 • Fever above 103°F.
 • Short-lived arthritis or joint inflammation.
REASONS TO GET THE MMR VACCINE

• Measles and mumps still occur in the United States. • Mumps can cause deafness and in rare cases, sterility in males. • Complications caused by measles include subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), a rare, progressive fatal neurological disorder. • Measles, mumps and rubella can be harmful to a developing fetus if pregnant women are infected. • The MMR vaccine is safe.
The pneumococcal vaccine is used to prevent pneumococcus.
Before the vaccine, pneumococcus caused about 700 cases of meningitis, 17,000 cases of sepsis and 71,000 cases of pneumonia each year.
The pneumococcal vaccine is a conjugate vaccine.

• Pain and swelling at the injection site.
 • Fever (greater than 100.4°F).
 • High fever (greater than 102°F).
 • Decreased appetite • Irritability.
REASONS TO GET THE PNEUMOCOCCAL VACCINE

• Pneumococcus causes infections every year in the U.S.
 • Pneumococcal infections can complicate other infections.
 • Some pneumococcal infections do not respond to antibiotics.
 • The pneumococcal vaccine works.
 • The pneumococcal vaccine is safe.
The polio vaccine is used to prevent polio.
Before the polio vaccine, every year in the U.S. polio caused paralysis in tens of thousands of people and led to thousands of deaths.
The polio vaccine used in the U.S. is given as a shot; it is a killed viral vaccine. In some countries an oral polio vaccine is used and is a live, weakened viral vaccine.
• Redness, hardness and pain at the injection site.\n • Fever (greater than 102°F).
REASONS TO GET THE POLIO VACCINE

• Polio still exists.
 • Polio is highly contagious.
 • Paralytic polio, a severe and devastating disease, may occur.
 • A syndrome known as post-polio syndrome can occur later in life in people previously infected with polio.
 • The polio vaccine is safe.
The rotavirus vaccine is used to prevent rotavirus.
Before the vaccine, rotavirus caused illness in 2.7 million children every year, and virtually every child had a rotavirus infection by 5 years of age.
There are two rotavirus vaccines and both are live, weakened viral vaccines.
REASONS TO GET THE ROTAVIRUS VACCINE

• Every child will become infected with rotavirus by 5 years of age.
 • Some rotavirus infections can lead to hospitalization.
 • Rotavirus occurs throughout the world, no matter the level of sanitation.
 • The rotavirus vaccine is safe.
BCG vaccine is a vaccine primarily used against tuberculosis.
Among children it prevents about 20% from getting infected and among those who do get infected it protects half from developing disease.
The BCG vaccine is made from a weakened strain of TB bacteria.
• Injection scar\n • Allergy to the BCG vaccine.
REASONS TO GET THE BCG VACCINE

• Genetic variation in BCG strains.
 • Genetic variation in populations.
 • Interference by nontuberculous mycobacteria.
 • Interference by concurrent parasitic infection.
REASONS TO GET THE MCV4 VACCINE
• Meningococcal disease often occurs without warning – even among people who are otherwise healthy.\n • Meningococcal disease can spread from person to person through close contact.

• Sudden high fever.
 • Headache.
 • Stiff neck.
 • Fatigue.
Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is given as an injection into the fatty tissue of the upper arm.
Even when it is treated, meningococcal disease kills 10 to 15 infected people out of 100.
MCV4 vaccine is used to prevent meningococcal disease.

► Causes of child deaths in low-income countries:

Child Vaccine helps you track your baby\'s vaccinations while providing you with vaccines information, safety topics and Immunization statistics. ChildVaccine notify you with a reminder of vaccines needed for your child everytime the child reaches the required age. You can also ask a specialist doctor if you want to. ChildVaccine is available in both English and Arabic.
Click here to see vaccines needed.
